message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration throughout his body, including the lips and tongue, and the low oxygen saturation suggest a congenital heart defect. The chest X-ray shows a classic egg-shaped heart, which is seen in transposition of great vessels. All other options would present differently on examination or imaging.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration throughout the body, along with the low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, and low oxygen saturation, suggest a cyanotic congenital heart defect. The chest x-ray shows a boot-shaped heart, which is consistent with transposition of great vessels. Arteriovenous malformation, congenital diaphragmatic hernia, and esophageal atresia do not typically present with cyanosis and do not explain the findings on the chest x-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration, low oxygen saturation, and chest X-ray findings are typical of transposition of great vessels. Arteriovenous malformation and congenital diaphragmatic hernia can present with similar symptoms but would have different X-ray findings. Esophageal atresia would present with feeding difficulties and inability to pass a nasogastric tube.

We searched for information about the conditions in the options and found that transposition of great vessels is a congenital heart defect characterized by the reversal of the great arteries. This can cause cyanosis and low oxygen saturation, which is consistent with the baby's symptoms of bluish discoloration and low oxygen saturation. The single second heart sound without murmurs is also suggestive of transposition of great vessels. The chest X-ray may also show a narrow mediastinum, which is a typical finding in transposition of great vessels, although this is not provided in the exhibit. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is option (B) transposition of great vessels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration throughout the body, along with low oxygen saturation and a single second heart sound without murmurs points to transposition of great vessels, where the aorta is connected to the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery is connected to the left ventricle. Chest X-ray may show "egg on a string" appearance. Other options do not fit with the symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration throughout the body including lips and tongue, along with a single second heart sound without murmurs suggests Transposition of great vessels. Chest x-ray shows narrow mediastinum and egg-shaped heart. All other options have different physical examination or radiological findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration throughout the body, low oxygen saturation, and chest X-ray showing a narrow cardiac silhouette with a “snowman” configuration suggest transposition of great vessels. Arteriovenous malformation typically presents with a localized blue or red lesion. Congenital diaphragmatic hernia would cause respiratory distress and bowel sounds heard in the chest. Esophageal atresia would present with excessive salivation and absence of gastric bubble on X-ray.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The physical examination shows bluish discoloration, low blood pressure, and low oxygen saturation, which suggests a congenital heart defect. The chest X-ray confirms transposition of great vessels, which is the most likely diagnosis. Arteriovenous malformation, congenital diaphragmatic hernia, and esophageal atresia would all present with different signs and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration throughout the body suggests cyanosis, the low blood pressure and high heart rate suggest shock, and the chest X-ray shows a narrow mediastinum. These symptoms are consistent with transposition of great vessels, where the aorta and pulmonary artery are switched.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The bluish discoloration suggests cyanosis, and the chest X-ray shows a "egg-on-a-string" appearance, which is characteristic of transposition of the great vessels. Other options would have different physical exam findings and X-ray appearances.
